Anonymous Sources.Sourced Statement: District leadership — including Superintendent Kyla Johnson-Trammell, chief systems and services officer Preston Thomas, and risk management officer Rebecca Littlejohn — committed to transparency going forward and said a personnel investigation is underway to determine how communication broke down.
Anonymous Sources.Source Justification: District leadership — including Superintendent Kyla Johnson-Trammell, chief systems and services officer Preston Thomas, and risk management officer Rebecca Littlejohn — committed to transparency going forward.

Anonymous Sources.Sourced Statement: District leaders on Wednesday said the lead came from the water fixtures, such as a sink faucet or water fountain spigot, and denied that it was an issue with pipes or the water source.
Anonymous Sources.Source Justification: District leaders on Wednesday said the lead came from the water fixtures.

Anonymous Sources.Sourced Statement: School sites will continue to be tested in five stages, district leaders said.
Anonymous Sources.Source Justification: District leaders said school sites will continue to be tested in five stages.

Anonymous Sources.Sourced Statement: More of the FloWater stations are being delivered to schools this week, and schools will be prioritized based on the percentage of fountains that are out of service and the number of students that attend the school, Thomas said.
Anonymous Sources.Source Justification: Thomas said schools will be prioritized based on the percentage of fountains that are out of service and the number of students that attend the school.

Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: In an update at Wednesday’s school board meeting, parents, students and school staff demanded transparency and answers about why they were kept in the dark.
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: In an update at Wednesday’s school board meeting, parents, students and school staff demanded transparency and answers.

Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: Community members, many of whom raised concerns two weeks ago, were skeptical.
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: Community members, many of whom raised concerns two weeks ago, were skeptical.

Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: Teachers from Frick United Academy of Language demanded to know why, if testing took place in April, fountains weren’t shut down until August.
Unnamed Group of People.Name of Source: Teachers from Frick United Academy of Language
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: Teachers from Frick United Academy of Language demanded to know why fountains weren’t shut down until August.

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: An average of two months passed between when Oakland schools were tested for lead this spring and when those school communities were notified of high lead levels in August, according to a report from this week’s Oakland Unified school board meeting.
Document Sources.Source Justification: According to a report from this week’s Oakland Unified school board meeting.

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: In stage two, 15 elementary schools were tested between Aug. 17 and Aug. 22, requiring six fixtures to be repaired, according to the report.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “This mistake has caused families stress, anxiety and panic, further limiting our community’s trust in this district,” said Max Simmons, one of OUSD’s student directors.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Max Simmons, one of OUSD’s student directors.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “I sincerely apologize for the stress and concern this has caused our school sites, students and families. We understand the gravity of this situation and we are fully committed to taking immediate, transparent and corrective action,” she said.

“There is so much trust rebuilding that has to be done for our community. We have failed. And when I say ‘we’ I mean OUSD has failed at its most basic job of not poisoning our students,” said Stuart Loebl, a sixth-grade science teacher at Frick.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Stuart Loebl, a sixth-grade science teacher at Frick.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “Why didn’t you do your job? You knew months ago that the water was contaminated. You didn’t act, and you let those kids come back to school and drink poisoned water,” said Marina Muñoz, a parent at Madison Park Academy and an organizer with Communities for a Better Environment.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: parent at Madison Park Academy and an organizer with Communities for a Better Environment
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Marina Muñoz, a parent at Madison Park Academy and an organizer with Communities for a Better Environment.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “This is not new to Oakland, but it is something that we need to tackle as an entire city, and we need to have community partners, philanthropic partners, as well as our county and state folks to support us in dealing with this issue,” she said.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Director and chair of OUSD’s facilities committee
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Director Valarie Bachelor, the chair of OUSD’s facilities committee.

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: The district’s risk management team began testing water fixtures and faucets in April and continued through the summer, but it wasn’t until Aug. 10 that district officials realized school sites hadn’t been told about it or informed of the results.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: The district’s risk management team began testing water fixtures and faucets in April.

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: The district’s safe drinking water policy states that any water sources showing lead at above 5 parts per billion must be taken offline and repaired.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: The district’s safe drinking water policy.

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: OUSD also committed to redesigning its water quality website and publishing a dashboard by Jan. 1 for community members to view test results.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: OUSD also committed to redesigning its water quality website.
